front.title: Authentication Mechanism of Port Control Protocol (PCP)

abstract.t: A IPv6 or IPv4 host can use the Port Control Protocol (PCP) to flexibly re-configure its network address translators (NATs) or firewalls, change their ways in translating and forwarding IP packets, and eventually facilitate its communications with remote hosts. However, the un-controlled generation or deletion of IP address mappings on such network devices may cause security risks and should be avoided. Before a PCP request is eventually executed, the requester needs to prove that it is a legal PCP user and has a sufficient privilege. This document proposes an in-band authentication mechanism for PCP. The Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) is taken advantage of to perform authentication between PCP devices.
